Jon Vickers, tenor; Peter Schaaf, piano. VAI Audio 1007-2; two CD's. (VAI Audio, 158 Linwood Plaza, Fort Lee, N.J. 07024.)

This lovely and absorbing "Winterreise" was taped live in Toronto in October 1983, less than three months after Jon Vickers recorded Schubert's great cycle for EMI in Paris. The contrast is startling. In the studio recording, Mr. Vickers had taken the modern fondness for stretching out the opening song, "Gute Nacht," to new lengths, crossing the seven-minute mark. In Toronto, he took half a minute

In large part because the voice is in such good shape. The half-voice that forms the basis for this "Winterreise" is spun out freely and meltingly. (Compare the seemingly effortless opening phrases of this "Lindenbaum" with the strained studio version.) And from it this big voice can be opened out to wonderful effect, as in the "Was soll ich langer weilen" stanza of "Gute Nacht."

In the studio recording, the louds aren't much more persuasive than the softs, perhaps because of the way studio producers tend to compensate for full-size voices in lieder recordings. Mr. Vickers sounds as if he's relaxed and in control of the Toronto performance; what sounded self-conscious, even precious, before, here sounds fluid and grippingly personal.

The Toronto performance also benefits from a considerably more sympathetic accompanist. Going back to "Der Lindenbaum," compare Geoffrey Parsons's crisply efficient opening with the elegiac tone set here by Peter Schaaf, who seems to enjoy and take rich advantage of the singer's exploratory mode. Both singer and pianist are beautifully recorded.
